sen.j: 阿知女作法（あちめのわざ、あちめわざ、あちめさほう、あじめのさほう、等々）とは、宮中及び神社等で歌われる神楽歌の一つ。
sen.e: Achimenowaza (Achimewaza, Achimesaho, Ajimenosaho) is a Kagurauta (a song sung in Kagura [a performance of sacred Shinto music and dancing]) performed in the Imperial Court or shrines.
sen.cmt: 後列を一緒に訳出しました
sen.e: Achimenowaza (also known as Achimewaza, Achimesaho, Ajimenosaho, and so on) is a Kagurauta (songs to accompany kagura [sacred music and dancing performed at shrines] performance) performed in the Imperial Court or shrines.
sen.cmt: 原文が不適切に分割されていたため、一文にしました。
sen.e: Achimenowaza (also known as Achimewaza, Achimesaho, Ajimenosaho, and so on) is a Kagurauta (songs to accompany kagura [sacred music and dancing performed at shrines] performance) performed in the Imperial Court or shrines.

sen.j: 本来は、神の降臨を喜び、神聖な雰囲気を作るためと思われる一種の呪文。
sen.e: It was originally a kind of a magic spell to celebrate the advent of God and to create a sacred atmosphere.
It was originally a kind of a magic spell to celebrate the advent of God and to create a sacred atmosphere.
It was originally a kind of a magic spell to celebrate the advent of God and to create a sacred atmosphere.

sen.j: あ～ち～め―（一度）、お～お～お―（三度）、お～けー（一度）のフレーズを阿知女作法と呼び、これが２組（本方・末方）に分かれて唱和される。
sen.e: "Ah, Chih, Meh" (once), "Oh, Oh, Oh" (three times), "Oh, Keh" (once): this set of phrase is called Achimenowaza, and sung in chorus by two groups (motokata [leaders, sitting on the left side of the niwabi, a garden fire, at Mikagura, music performed in court shinto ceremonies] and suikata [followers, sitting on the right side of the niwabi).

"Ah, Chih, Meh" (once), "Oh, Oh, Oh" (three times), "Oh, Keh" (once): This set of phrase is called Achimenowaza, and sung in chorus by two groups (motokata [leaders, sitting on the left side of the niwabi, a garden fire, at Mikagura, music performed in court Shinto ceremonies] and suikata [followers, sitting on the right side of the niwabi]).

"Ah, Chih, Meh" (once), "Oh, Oh, Oh" (three times), "Oh, Keh" (once): This set of phrase is called Achimenowaza, and sung in chorus by two groups (motokata [leaders, sitting on the left side of the niwabi, a garden fire, at Mikagura, music performed in court Shinto ceremonies] and suikata [followers, sitting on the right side of the niwabi]).

sen.j: 神楽歌は、庭燎（にわび：夜の準備）、採物（とりもの：神迎え）、前張（さいばり：神祭り）、明星（あかぼし：神送り）の段階に大きく分けられる。
sen.e: Kagurauta is roughly divided into the following parts: Niwabi (preparation for the night), Torimono (greeting the gods), Saibari (entertainment for the gods), and Akaboshi (sending off the gods).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 「夜の準備」の意味がわかりませんでしたが、文字通り訳出しました
sen.e: Kagurauta is roughly divided into the following parts: Niwabi (preparation for the night), Torimono (greeting the gods), Saibari (entertainment for the gods), and Akaboshi (sending off the gods).
Kagurauta is roughly divided into the following parts: Niwabi (preparation for the night), Torimono (greeting the gods), Saibari (entertainment for the gods), and Akaboshi (sending off the gods).

sen.j: 阿知女作法で有名なものは庭燎の後に、また、採物、前張 等でもフレーズを変えて繰り返される。
sen.e: The most common way of Achimenowaza is that after the part of Niwabi, a variation of the phrase is repeated in the part of Torimono or Maebari.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The most common way of Achimenowaza is that after the part of Niwabi, a variation of the phrase is repeated in the part of Torimono or Maebari, and so on.
The most common way of Achimenowaza is that after the part of Niwabi, a variation of the phrase is repeated in the part of Torimono or Maebari, and so on.

sen.j: 鎮魂祭の歌（下記）にも使用される。
sen.e: It is also used for a song sung in Chinkonsai (a service for the repose of the dead) as described below.
It is also used for a song sung in Chinkonsai (a service for the repose of the dead) as described as follows.
It is also used for a song sung in Chinkonsai (a service for the repose of the dead) as described as follows.

sen.j: 平安中期には儀礼として完成していた。
sen.e: It reached completion as a ceremonial song in the mid Heian period.
It reached completion as a ceremonial song in the mid Heian period.
It reached completion as a ceremonial song in the mid Heian period.

sen.j: 延喜末年頃に譜の統一が行われている。
sen.e: In the late Engi era, its music note was standardized.
In the late Engi era (around 912 to 923), its music note was standardized.
In the late Engi era (around 912 to 923), its music note was standardized.

sen.j: 十一月中寅日 鎮魂祭歌
sen.e: On the second Day of the Tiger in November: Chinkonsai song
On the second Day of the Tiger (one of the twelve animals of the oriental zodiac in Chinese calendar) in November: Chinkonsai song
On the second Day of the Tiger (one of the twelve animals of the oriental zodiac in Chinese calendar) in November: Chinkonsai song

sen.j: 意味が判明していないところが多く、漢字を当てたとしても、その漢字が意味と合っているかも判っていない。
sen.e: Most of the meanings are obscure; if a kanji character is used to express each meaning, it is uncertain whether the kanji accurately corresponds to the meaning.

sen.j: 歌なので、音はそれほど変遷していないとの仮定で、ひらがな表記とした。
sen.e: Since it is a song, its sound is assumed not to be greatly changed; so it is described in the hiragana syllabary as stated above.
Since it is a song, its sound is assumed not to be greatly changed; so it is described in the hiragana syllabary as stated above.

sen.j: 「あちめ」とは、男神と考えられている安曇磯良を指すといわれ、「お～お～お―」とは、安曇磯良が返答している声との説（太平記等）がある。
sen.e: One theory is that "Achime" indicates "Azumi no Isora," a male god, and "Oh, Oh, Oh" is Azumi no Isora's response. (Taiheiki [The Record of the Great Peace] and others).
One theory is that 'Achime' refers to 'Azumi no Isora,' a male god, and 'Oh, Oh, Oh' is Azumi no Isora's response (in Taiheiki [The Record of the Great Peace] and others).
sen.cmt: 表記などを変えました。
sen.e: One theory is that 'Achime' refers to 'Azumi no Isora,' a male god, and 'Oh, Oh, Oh' is Azumi no Isora's response (in Taiheiki [The Record of the Great Peace] and others).

sen.j: しかし、後世に当て字したものだろうか、「阿知女」と、「女」の漢字がついており、詳細は不明である。
sen.e: However, now that "Achime" is expressed in kanji characters as "阿知女," in which the character "女" meaning "woman" is used, these kanji must have been used as phonetic symbols rather than for the meanings in later years; however, details are still unknown.

However, now that 'Achime' is expressed in kanji characters as '阿知女,' in which the character '女' meaning 'woman' is used, these kanji must have been used as phonetic symbols rather than for the meanings in later years; however, details are still unknown.

However, now that 'Achime' is expressed in kanji characters as '阿知女,' in which the character '女' meaning 'woman' is used, these kanji must have been used as phonetic symbols rather than for the meanings in later years; however, details are still unknown.

sen.j: また、「アメノウズメ」の転訛との説もある（愚案抄）。
sen.e: Another theory is that "Ameno uzume" (goddess of entertainment) was corrupted into "Achime." (Guansho [commentary book on Kagurauta])
sen.cmt: 「愚案抄」は「梁塵愚案抄」として訳出しました
sen.e: Another theory is that 'Ameno uzume' (goddess of entertainment) was corrupted into 'Achime' (in Guansho [commentary book on Kagurauta]).
Another theory is that 'Ameno uzume' (goddess of entertainment) was corrupted into 'Achime' (in Guansho [commentary book on Kagurauta]).

sen.j: ①「ゆらかす（振らかす）」の言葉が使われており、鎮魂祭にあたり、天皇の衣を動揺させることを歌った可能性がある。
sen.e: ① The word "yurakasu (furakasu)" used in this part possibly means to shake Emperor's clothes ready for Chinkonsai.
1. The word 'yurakasu' or 'furakasu' used in this part possibly means to shake Emperor's clothes ready for Chinkonsai.
1. The word 'yurakasu' or 'furakasu' used in this part possibly means to shake Emperor's clothes ready for Chinkonsai.

sen.j: 「きね」とは巫女である可能性もあるとされる。
sen.e: "Kine" possibly means "shrine maiden."
Kine' possibly means 'shrine maiden.'
Kine' possibly means 'shrine maiden.'

sen.j: ②「いそのかみ ふるやしろ」とは石上神宮を指していると考えられる。
sen.e: ② "Isonokami furuyashiro" probably indicates the Isonokami-jinja Shrine.
2. 'Isonokami Furuyashiro' probably refers to the Isonokami-jinja Shrine.
2. 'Isonokami Furuyashiro' probably refers to the Isonokami-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: ③「さつお」とは猟夫と漢字で当て、猟師のこととされる。
sen.e: ③ "Satsuo," which can be expressed in kanji characters as "猟夫," means " hanter."
3. 'Satsuo,' which can be expressed in kanji characters as '猟夫,' means ' hunter.'
3. 'Satsuo,' which can be expressed in kanji characters as '猟夫,' means ' hunter.'

sen.j: ④「とよひるめ」とは天照大神であるとされる。
sen.e: ④ "Toyohirume" means "Amaterasu Omikami" (the Sun Goddess).
4. 'Toyohirume' is said to refer to 'Amaterasu Omikami' (the Sun Goddess).
4. 'Toyohirume' is said to refer to 'Amaterasu Omikami' (the Sun Goddess).

sen.j: 「ほこ」は矛であるとされるが、意味不明。
sen.e: "Hoko" probably means "halberd;" however, it is not certain.
Hoko' probably means 'halberd;' however, it is not certain.
Hoko' probably means 'halberd;' however, it is not certain.

sen.j: ⑤「みわやま」は三輪山である。
sen.e: ⑤ "Miwayama" refers to Mt. Miwa.
5. 'Miwayama' refers to Mt. Miwa.
5. 'Miwayama' refers to Mt. Miwa.

sen.j: 「ちかさ」は茅草の転訛とする説もある。
sen.e: One theory is that "chigusa" (a cogon-grass) was corrupted into "chikasa."
One theory is that 'chigusa' (a cogon-grass) was corrupted into 'chikasa.'
One theory is that 'chigusa' (a cogon-grass) was corrupted into 'chikasa.'

sen.j: ⑥「みやまかづら」とは、山蔓などで作った鬘という説がある。
sen.e: ⑥ There is a theory that "miyamakazura" means "hair ornament" made of Yamakazura (club moss).
6. There is a theory that 'Miyamakazura' means 'hair ornament' made of Yamakazura (club moss).
6. There is a theory that 'Miyamakazura' means 'hair ornament' made of Yamakazura (club moss).

sen.j: ⑦「たまはこ」とは、魂の鎮まる函。
sen.e: ⑦ "Tamahako" means "box" in which spririts are enshrined.
7. 'Tamahako' means 'box' in which spirits are enshrined.
7. 'Tamahako' means 'box' in which spirits are enshrined.

sen.j: 実際には葛函という。
sen.e: It is actually called "Katsurabako 葛函."
It is actually called Katsurabako (葛函).
It is actually called Katsurabako (葛函).

sen.j: ⑧「たまかへしすなや」は、「ゆっくりお留め申すがよい」と訳す説もある。
sen.e: ⑧ The theory goes that "tamakaeshisunaya" means "You may ask god to stay longer."
sen.cmt: 誰を「ゆっくりお留め申す」のかわかりませんでしたが、神として訳出しました
sen.e: 8. The theory goes that 'Tamakaeshisunaya' refers to 'You may ask to stay longer.'
8. The theory goes that 'Tamakaeshisunaya' refers to 'You may ask to stay longer.'

sen.j: ⑨数を１から10まで数えており、十種神宝の呪法として有名な「ひふみの祓詞」と関係があると考えられる。
sen.e: ⑨ Numbers are counted from 1 to 10; this may be related to "Hifumi no haraekotoba" known as a magic spell of Tokusa no kandakara (the ten sacred treasure).

9. Numbers are counted from 1 to 10; this may be related to 'Hifumi no Haraekotoba' (counting words read by the priest in a Shinto purification rite) known as a magic spell of Tokusa no kandakara (the ten sacred treasure).
sen.cmt: 表記を変え、用語補足しました。
sen.e: 9. Numbers are counted from 1 to 10; this may be related to 'Hifumi no Haraekotoba' (counting words read by the priest in a Shinto purification rite) known as a magic spell of Tokusa no kandakara (the ten sacred treasure).
